text: (gentle rock music)
- Thanks for joining us here today.
My name is Ellen,

I'm with AWS Innovation &
Transformation Programs,

and I'm with Matt Kaplan,
CEO of PeaceLove Foundation,
and Eric Rice, chief Creative Officer
of PeaceLove Foundation,

and we're here to talk
about the innovation journey
to create Scribl.
- [Matt] Thank you for having us.
- Thank you.
- Matt, can you just start us out

by telling us a little bit
about PeaceLove and the focus?
- Absolutely.
So at a high level, our mission

is to help people create peace
in their minds and lives.
The way that we do that is

we design and deliver
expressive arts programs
in a variety of settings.
So we work with kids, teens, adults,
we work with schools, healthcare systems,
veterans organizations.

Again, really with the
goal of giving people

permission to talk about
their mental health

and using creativity as
the catalyst to do that.
- That's fantastic.
So when we started together,
there was a big challenge on the table
and really interesting to think,

how are we gonna take
what you do every day
and tackle the particular challenge?
Can you tell us about what it was?
- Yeah, I mean, aspirationally,

we've always had big dreams
of reaching millions.

The need is there. There's
so much need, right?

So for us over the last
14 years, you know,

we've impacted about a
hundred thousand individuals
and we're proud of that.
But I think, you know,
now that we've set this goal in 2024
of reaching a million people,
we're on our way to doing that, right?

Having had a successful
pilot, and I think, you know,

using the working backwards
framework, you know,

we have been able to set
ourselves up to, you know,

reach probably many, many
more millions of people.

- Well, you have a digital
modality now, right?
And it's so much, it's like,
anybody can pick it up and use it, right?

So now the effort is
not in the human effort

to get people together and
do the longer interaction

and train creators, but
now you have something
that anybody can pick up and use,
and really what's the-

It's hard to have a limit
to the scale of that.

Anybody who can get their
hands on it can use it.
So you could get to a billion, right?
I mean, basically you no longer

have something standing
in the way of your scale.

- [Eric] Exactly.
- Right. Yeah.

And as you know, we've
talked about, right,
we're starting in the workplace,
but there are so many applications
even to be thinking about,

what would a single
player version look like?
We talked about the different communities

that have already expressed
interest in this tool.
So I think we'll continue to, you know,
dream big and set our sights high

and, you know, just
continue to do the work.

- You're becoming a company
offering digital products.
This is a transformation for you.
- Very much so.

You know, we've always used
technology in the background

for databases and filming
and things like that,
but at no point did we ever think
we were gonna become a tech company.
We were proudly analog.

We actually told people,
turn off your phones,

turn off your laptops,
get your hands dirty,

make some art together,
because it truly worked.

But now we've had to kind of
embrace the opposite of that.
It's a little scary.
- When we first started working together,

we shared a bit about our
culture of innovation at Amazon,

and we looked at our
working backwards mechanism
where we reframe problems through the lens
of what the customers might want or need,

not thinking so much about
organizational goals,
but more thinking about our customers.
And then we work to define

the most important problem
to solve for those customers

and start with something
quite specific as an invention
that we can then test and iterate upon

in order to bring a
solution to life quickly.
What was that process like for you,

moving away from your goal,
to scale, to a million

to start looking at,
but who's the customer?

- Working backwards made
us completely rethink
how we would scale our programs.
For years, like Matt mentioned,
we were for everybody and anyone,

but at the end of the day,
that wasn't going to be,

we couldn't just build bigger,
we had to build smarter.
And so through working backwards,
we identified several personas,
people with emotions and families and jobs

and all these things
that rounded them out,
and then we looked at the intersection
of what do they have in common?
And we found the workplace.

Struggles in the workplace,
struggles connecting,
struggles with trust,

and also coming out of
the pandemic, it was-
Hybrid was taking over and it was a lot.
- Yeah, and we dove into this work
right in the throes of the pandemic.
So for us as an organization,

it was actually our first
opportunity to use, like,
virtual platforms, right?
We were doing Zoom workshops,

we were doing our trainings
via, you know, teams.
So it was our first experience of like,

not being with people and holding
people and hugging people,
so it was really different for us.
And it didn't always feel great.
And I think that really helped us

as we got into the working
backwards, is like,
we better stretch our comfort zones here.

And especially where we
landed with digital first.
- And we found many personas,

and there are many that
we can still look back
and go back and serve moving forward,
but we're starting with one place
for the very good first place to start
to do something new, right?

And we chose the adult,
and the adult goes to work,
that's part of the life,
but it's also integrating their family
and their social pressures and aspects.
And so where can you meet people

and potentially meet many
people as a starting point?
What's the front door to meet them?
It can be through the workplace.
And many organizations are interested
in bringing wellness to their employees.
And so that's where we decided to start.

Now, I know we looked at
many potential solutions.
So what was that about?
Framing the challenge, you know,

and then how do you decide
what's the right thing to build
once you know what the problem is, right?
- Working backwards really helped us

to find exactly the person
that we wanted to serve.
And then we put that idea out

to all sorts of different
friends, companies, partners,
asking for ideas.

And what we got back, we
were able to take a look at,
reflect on, iterate on,
and really refine for that segment

what would be the best
product to put out there.
- What did you end up with?

- We got five ideas that kind
of made it to the, you know,

to the Shark Tank or,
you know, to the pitch.
We had like,

a co-branded Mr. Potato
Head expressive arts kit

that like an employee could
do with their kids, right?
- Can I have that too?

- You can have it, yeah.
(Ellen laughs)
It didn't get selected,
but we had a robot for in your home
that could be like a virtual, you know,
healthcare assistant.

We had a virtual in the
Metaverse where you could,
I think it was called Story World,

where people would share
their mental health journeys
through some type of a creative output,
and you could learn

about what other people
were going through, right?
So we had, it ran the scope of, you know,

analog to digital, but-
- [Ellen] To highly tech.
- Yeah, to high tech.
And we actually landed on something

that I think we were
really comfortable with,

which was a game called Pieces
of Mind, at the time, right?
Where, an analog game, a board game,

that would bring people
together, you know,
help people connect.
And that game, as much as we loved it,
through the working backwards process,
we're all sitting there

and we're going through this
exercise and we're like,
"Are we gonna sell a million board games?"
Like, who sells a million board games?
- Right. Do we lose the scale?
So we've got something people love to do,

everybody who sits down
and does this feels great.
How do we bring it into the workplace
and will it scale to a million, right?
What's the process there?
I know we had a document
where we were writing down the vision

and asking these hard
questions and having debates,
where did we go?
- The one nice part about the analog game

is it really helped us identify
the core of our modality.

You know, we ask people or we
give them space to be creative
and tell us a story.
And it worked as an analog game,

and so when we decided to
pivot into the digital game,

I think we weren't as scared
to approach technology

like we had been in the past.
- Yeah, but it was also like,
there was like an a-ha moment when,
you were there, there were 20 of us
around a table playing a game,
and we all kind of looked at each other,
and I think it was Sanju who said,

"Well, why don't we just
do this digital first?"

And, you know, we were,
that sounded great.

You know, we've never done
anything digital in our life.
So for us it was...
- Right.

If we're drawing on a paper,
could we draw on our phone?
- And I think over the course of that,
the next two hours, right?

We whiteboarded how we
would take a analog game

and how we would convert
it to a digital product.
And it was fun.

- Yeah.
- It was fun.

- And we ended up selecting
that as our pilot product.

And we set out to build
that MLP right from there.
- We talk about customer testimonials

and what do customers say
and what do customers feel
and what a customer's, you know, we test,

how do customers think
about this new concept?

You've been taking it around,
you've been sharing it,
I know we piloted it at Amazon
through our Epic Leadership Program.
I know we had more than 500 sessions
and amazing feedback at Amazon,
what else are you hearing out there?
- Oh, it's surreal. It's surreal.
- Definitely.
The things that we never thought of
when we put it out into the world.

Companies telling us that
they're having better meetings,
more productive meetings.
One of my favorite stories is a AWS leader

who was using it and had
never heard the voice
of somebody on his team before.
- Wow.
- They were always in the meeting
and they were always present
and they always got their work done,
but they had never spoken up.

And now those people who
are never speaking up

are the ones talking the most
when it comes to the game.

- So explain a little bit
what the experience is
so that everybody can understand
what is it that we do together

that makes people suddenly
be able to engage,
to feel that they're included,

to have their voice heard,
to feel comfortable.
What is this process?

- Yeah, so our approach is
bringing people together, right?
And building meaningful connections.

So the process is, you
take out your phone,

you scan a QR code, a
host is running the game,
a prompt hits the screen, it might be,
"'Blank' gives me peace of mind,"
and everybody has 60 seconds.
Most people take 30.

And you scribble with
your finger on a phone.

And it is about the process,
it's not about the product.
And it is fun, it is easy to engage with.

And it is amazing how many
barriers that breaks down
'cause when it comes to sharing now,

you see this cool game
board, all these pieces,
all this art, and then you share.

- I see my dog on the screen.
- Exactly. Exactly.
- And then I get to talk about it.

- And then I learn that you
have a dog and I have a dog,
and we connect and you know,

it just really breaks down
all these barriers that exist,
especially in the hybrid work environment.
To Eric's point earlier,

some people aren't included
in the conversation.

You know, there are people
that have great ideas,
but, you know, might not just jump in
and be the first to talk.
So this levels the playing field.

I think you said it earlier,
it's like a door opener,
like an on-ramp.

And what we find, if there
were 10 of us playing,
and it's a 10 minute game,

it's probably closer
to a seven minute game,
you will learn, and we've heard this,

"I've learned more about
my fellow coworkers,"

or "I've learned more about
my boss in a seven minute game
than I have in two years."
- Yeah. It's really amazing.

I've done it with teams
that I've been part of
and I feel like we've scribbled together.

It's like we have this thing
that we've done together,

we're connected in that way,
and we learned from each other.
And I also learned such interesting things
about what people love and don't love
about their job day to day.
I mean, everybody just starts to share.

Like, it's safe to have an
opinion, it's safe to share

because there's been a
space held for sharing.
- Yeah, and that safety piece is huge.

And that's like, that's what
we do in our other work, right?

You build this space, you
allow people to be vulnerable,

and once you're allowed
to be vulnerable, like,
transformation happens, you know this,
this is what you guys do, right?

So for us to see it happen
at a corporate level, right,

with, you know, adults that
have their stuff together,

but we're all dealing with
so many challenges, right?

- We all have something
on our mind. Absolutely.

- We all do and, you know, I
think if you can do something

that is already embedded
in your existing workflow,

like, it's not another
thing you have to do
or another meeting you have to take,

and after seven minutes and
you're like, "That felt good."
Like, "Let's do that weekly."

And that's what this
gentleman Chris has been doing
with his team, he's like,

"I do it every Monday
morning to stand up my week."
- Yeah, absolutely.

So what are some of the
routines you're seeing?

- I mean, obviously, we
have the data in our backend
and it's fun to look at,

but we as an organization,
we tell stories.
And so we're going out to these hosts

that have been piloting
the program and saying,

"Tell us your stories. Tell
us exactly what's happening."
And what we're hearing back the most is,

"It's helping my team build
the emotional data set

that has been missing
for the past few years."
And that emotional data set is necessary
for things like trust and connection.

And just knowing your
coworker as a human being,
not just a little box on the screen.

- And then I wanna rush
home and do it with my kids
and doing it with my church group.

I wanna take it around to
people that I care about
and connect with them too, right?
And that's how this can scale.
Let's talk about scale a little bit.
So we've gotten specific,
we were first gonna serve all people,
and then we narrowed down and said,

"Wow can we focus on the
adult in the workplace?"

How do we now reach back?
How big can that be?

And how do we reach back to
get as big as we can with this?

Like, how does that process
work for you in your mind?

- So, the easiest way
to answer that question

is, I think it's limitless
how many people we can reach.
Right?

I know that when having
worked with Epic, right,

their goal is to impact
a billion people, right?
That's a real number that they talk about
and it's possible, right?

So I think for us, the
most interesting thing,
and maybe one of the most rewarding things

is when we play this game
and we show it to somebody,
everybody has a use case in their head.
Like, "Hey, I would love to do this
with my faith-based group,"

or "I work with veterans, and
this would be like a great way
to kick off, you know, a meeting."
One example,

we work with a very large group
in the mental health space,
they work with underinsured
or uninsured youth through schools.

So they're like, "Every
counselor should have this game

and they should use it as like
their orientation to like,
for teachers."

Yeah.
- Tool for connection, right?
- Exactly.

So I think really quickly,
and fortunately for us,

we had to pick a lane
and focus on that lane,

which we have for the
last year and a half.
And we're proofing that out.
But I think to answer your question,
I think there's limitless opportunities.
I think it could benefit any community

- We pick so that we can
be really intentional

in what we're gonna build
and test and iterate

and it's okay to fail if
we're starting somewhere
that's actionable and smaller.
But the idea is, of course,

that we're gonna look and
see how big can it be, right?
With every invention.

Really excited to see
all that's coming along.
Having taken this journey with us,

and knowing that there are so
many organizations out there

that have massive
challenges ahead of them.

They have maybe a
backlog of a lot of ideas
they'd like to see come to life,

they're not quite sure which
ones are the ones to focus on,
and/or they have massive challenges
that they need to tackle and overcome.
What advice could you give them

after going through this
process might resonate?
- Trust it. Trust the process.

You know, we were just
talking about other segments,
opening up new segments.

We're gonna go back and
we're going to do it again,

and we're going to refine the
product for those segments.
We now have that tool set

that we learned through working
backwards to do it properly.

- Yeah, the only thing I
would add to that is, I mean,

we stretched our comfort zone
like you can't imagine, right?

- Well, I saw you do it.
- Yeah, no, I know, I know.

So, but, it was, and you
know, as scary as that is,

and as challenging as that
was, it was super rewarding

because we're not gonna
reach a million people
doing how we did it.
It was scary.

But now that we're kind of
going through the process,

my advice would just be:
You've gotta take chances.

You know, especially if you
want to solve for something
as challenging as like, mental health
or emotional wellbeing, or like, you know,

how do you develop
empathy in the workplace?

Like, these are big things.
- Big problems.
- They're big problems, right?

So for us it was, you know,
honor our modality, right?
Like, honor what we do,
what we do is we give people permission
to talk about their mental health

or their emotional health
by using creativity.

And it's gotta be fun. And
it's gotta be easy, right?

'Cause working on our mental
health can be hard work.
And nobody's looking for like, more tools

to like, dig deeper,
they wanna like, let go.
- One of the things I love about it

is that it's this doorway
that's there, but it's fast.

It's easy to enter and
it is fun to be creative

and it is fun to talk
about the creativity,
but it's so bite-sized at first.
Like, just draw something. Okay.
That felt great.
- Yeah. And back to your question,
'cause I think this is really important.
He said, "Trust the process."
Like, we don't get here
if we aren't partnered with you guys.
If we're not partnered with Slalom,
we were smart enough to know that hey,

we're gonna need people that
not only have the expertise,

but, you know, can actually
help us build this.

Because as a nonprofit,
you are not going out
and raising substantial dollars
to build a new technology product,
at least in our case, right?
So we had to be really thoughtful

about how we talked about
this, how we approached it.
And I think it's the greatest investment
that we've ever made as a company

'cause we are gonna, we
have the opportunity now

to truly impact, you know,
many, many more lives.
- Let's take it to a billion.

- We're up for it.
- Okay.

One last thought, too, is
that you said "It's scary"
and I was thinking about defining that.
I think it's vulnerable.

- In the same way that
we give people permission

to talk about their feelings,
AWS has given us permission
to dream as big as we possibly could.
And while that can be a little bit scary,

you've been so reassuring
during the process.
I think one of my favorite times
was during the solutions workshop
when I was talking to Sanju Soni

about how should we end this
game and we had an idea,
and it was kind of crazy at the time.
It was very much out of the realm
of what we were normally doing.

And I asked, I said,
"Is this even possible?"
And he said, "Of course it's possible."
He kind had this little smile and he said,
"We're Amazon, we can do anything."

- Well with technology,
we can do anything.
And the hard part is-
Or most anything, and the hard part is,

how do we frame the problems
in the right size and shape

where we know exactly
what we need to go do
and we can test and measure it.
And how do we start

with something that we
could build upon, right?

If we try to boil the ocean
and take the biggest problem
and have the best big idea
that anybody's ever seen the first time

and we're afraid to be
wrong, that's really hard.
But if we can give ourselves permission

to start with something
that seems actionable
and then see how good we could be,
we can test, improve, and get there.
That's not hard. That's fun, right?

But the vulnerability
piece is a big part of it.

And just being vulnerable
about being honest

about where are we and how
much do we know our customer
or not know our customer,

and how honest are we being
about where we need to go.

And then I think we work
through that process a lot,
like, in our partnership,

and that as you bring
partners into the fold,

they can continue to
follow along the process
in order to make sense of it.

- And I love that, I
don't know who said it,

but it was like, you know,
if you can do something,

you know, because we always
want it to be perfect.

You know, we want to give
like our best effort.

We wanna put the best
product in front of people.

And you know, thinking
about kind of just like,

the foundational MLP,
like, what do we need?
It needs to work.
People need to be able to log in,
it needs to have a decent user experience.
We need to collect some data.

And you know, we, historically
would've pushed that off

months and months and months
until we had this feature
and that bell and that whistle.

And I think just saying,
"Hey, this is good enough.

Let's get it out there and let's
get that input from users."

I mean-
- Yeah.
We call it the "Minimum Lovable Product."

I think Sanjay probably
talked a lot about that.
So the Minimum Lovable Product,
what's the first thing that we can deliver

to find out whether that
benefit we wanna deliver

is truly gonna be impactful
the way we think it will.
Right?

And we learned through that
and we tested, we changed.

We changed direction a few
times based on feedback
and what we needed to emphasize

and how we needed to bring
people into the game.
So it's been a really great journey.

I just really wanna
thank you for joining us
and for sharing the journey

and we look forward to more.
- Thank you.

- We love you guys.
- Thank you.

- It's been really rewarding.
(uplifting rock music)
